import Prerequisites from '@site/src/components/Prerequisites'; import LearningObjective from '@site/src/components/LearningObjective'; import Outcome from '@site/src/components/Outcome'; import SuccessCriteria from '@site/src/components/SuccessCriteria'; import Exercise from '@site/src/components/Exercise'; import Checkpoint from '@site/src/components/Checkpoint'; Chapter 1: Sensor Integration in Simulation This chapter covers the integration of common sensors like cameras, LiDAR, and IMUs in a simulation environment.

You should have a robot model in URDF and be able to spawn it in Gazebo.
  • Understand how sensors are simulated in Gazebo.
  • Learn how to add a camera, LiDAR, and IMU to a URDF model.
  • Be able to visualize sensor data in RViz2.
 Gazebo Sensor Plugins In Gazebo, sensors are implemented as plugins. These plugins generate sensor data based on the state of the simulated world and publish it to ROS 2 topics. To add a sensor to your robot, you need to add a block to your URDF or SDF file and configure the appropriate plugin. Camera A camera sensor simulates a real-world camera, publishing images to a ROS 2 topic. You can configure the camera's resolution, frame rate, and other parameters. The gazeboroscamera plugin is commonly used for this. LiDAR A LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) sensor measures distances by emitting laser beams. In Gazebo, a LiDAR sensor plugin simulates this by casting rays into the environment and calculating the distances to objects. The data is typically published as a sensormsgs/msg/LaserScan or sensormsgs/msg/PointCloud2 message. IMU An IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) measures a robot's orientation, angular velocity, and linear acceleration. A Gazebo IMU plugin simulates the readings of a real IMU, often with configurable noise models to make the simulation more realistic.

What is the role of a Gazebo plugin in sensor simulation?
